Overview

Finnic languages, or Balto-Finnic languages, form a branch of the Uralic language family and are spoken in Estonia, Finland, Russia and Latvia

  • Finnish
  • Karelian
  • Veps
  • Estonian
  • Veps
  • VÃµro

Characteristics

Finnic languages in general are known to possess the following charcateristics:

  1. Vowel length
  2. Morphological gradation
  3. Vowel harmony
  4. Front rounded vowels

For more information please see the video below.

Personal Notes

As a non-Finnic person myself who has been learning one Finnic language (Standard Estonian), the Finnic languages present an interesting oppurtunity to learn one of the few non-Indo-European languages within Europe. It is quite unfortunate that most of the documentation on the minor Finnic languages is written in Russian, Finnish and Estonian, making them unaccessible for people from beyond these areas to learn more about them.
